title: An important read
content: Trust is a most interesting, philosophical novel. It is written in 4 parts.  Part one is a complete novella.  Part 2 is an incomplete memoir, telling a story similar to Part one.  Part 3 is a complete memoir of the woman who assisted the first person narrator of Part 2. Part 4 is the diary of a key character in Parts 1-3, whose story is not understood until Part 4 is read. Trust raises the question - Which is the true story?  Can it ever be fully known? Or is it always a matter of perspective? What is most interesting about Trust is that it is also the story of the world of finance, and raises similar questions in that world.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Warning -- there's a bit of a reveal here. This novel, written in 4 parts, requires patience to find out what it's about, and if one sticks with it to the end, the reader realizes that it has been worth it. Written in 4 parts that from the titles of each seemed to be unconnected, when I started, I had no idea just what was going on. Was this single novel in fact going to  be a group of 4 different stories? The first part I found difficult going, the writing style stilted and dated, though the story was interesting in an odd way. And then I moved on to part 2 and began to see that there might be a connection, maybe, but it wasn't clear just what -- but the writing style changed dramatically. Part 3 again is different, now a far more accessible writing style, and this is where we learn the tie between parts 1 and 3. The novel finishes with part 4, which in a way is a sort of epilogue, with a major twist on the truth of parts 1-3. Ultimately, when all the parts are integrated by the reader, this is a powerful book about the worlds of wealth in NY in the early 20th century, but more about personal relationships, ego, and self-deception. Well worth reading.

title: Circles within circles
content: Hernan Diaz’s “Trust” is exceptional. He builds a story around a mythical financier whose actions and audacity appear to have created the Great Depression followed quickly by the untimely death of his wife. However the straightforward way I have described the book is not the way the reader experiences it. Diaz plays with perception and the public mind. First we read the story as discussed in a roman a clef that details a fictionalized version of the story (a fiction of a fiction). Thus we begin this story casting the characters in exaggerated versions of themselves. Then we churn through the notes of the financier prepared for his memoirs. The reader then sees a self serving perspective to the events, confirmed by the third perspective provided by the erstwhile ghostwriter of those memoirs as she recounts her observations of the man who never quite measured up to the titan described in the memoirs. Throughout, we are tantalized by the wife, a figure who dominates the narrative over the protests of the husband and author who try to minimize her.

title: Well written, well researched, but....
content: "Trust", a fictitious, generational history of a wealthy American clan, is in parts an interesting read. How the novel garnered a Pulitzer, however, I will never fathom. Its narrative is like a musical composition that uses stops, odd bars, crescendos, diminuendos, and other devices to mask a lack of cohesion and purpose in its structure. No matter how much the author plays with time and setting or random story notes, the story lacks emotional depth and full characters that mean something to the reader. In its cold detachment, "Trust" resembles "Succession" the successful streaming show about another rich, powerful American family business. The book is a more serious artistic and historical effort, but like "Succession", takes itself too seriously and loses its way telling the story of how the rich live and rule the world. "Trust" is a similar soap opera, but without the sex and profanity required to gather TV viewers. The book was worth reading and finishing, but left me longing for the richer historical fiction of authors like Erik Larsen or a really good non-fiction history tome.

title: unexpected  ending
content: A captivating "page turner" with enough complexity to, as Diaz suggests of good literature, "exist in the vague space between the intellectual and the emotional."  I give it five stars.  That said, I do think Diaz "bends and aligns reality" to fit the ideal that he hopes to convey vis-a-vis gender politics.  I fully agree that women, especially in decades past, were unfairly subjugated to minor roles, while men took the glory.  But I think, in reality, two things can be true; women were unfairly repressed, AND men like Ford, Carnegie, Vanderbilt, Rockefeller, etc. etc., etc., can be rightfully commended for achieving greatness.  Then again, I'm not certain that one can garner a Pulitzer these days without turning up the volume (to distorted levels) on racism, bigotry, misogyny, etc.; though I think society is beginning to grow weary of the level to which these themes have been a bit exaggerated --and wise to the not-so-subtle misandry that's often pedaled as justice.

content: This is a fictional narrative first, but learned a lot about booms and busts of the Stock Exchange over its long history.  Format tells the story from different perspectives and draws the reader into the mystery and intrigue of the truth. The last section is of 4 parts is truly gripping and a twist is revealed.  Writing is beautifully written and number of good metaphors convey real emotion. Book will bring you into the world of wealth and happiness and a little madness. How metal heath was treated in the 1920s brought to the surface as well as questioning on happy marriage of soulmates. Don’t want to reveal too much more.
